loans.use: To purchase young cattle in order to expand the business and improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Jane  Nakku ‘S Group

texts.en:
Jane is the leader of a five member group. She is 37 years old and married with two children, ages 12 and 14. Both of her children go to school. She also takes care of her old mother. She resides in a rented two-roomed house in which four people stay. They have electricity and piped water at home and the family gets three meals a day. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.

Jane deals in second-hand clothing in the Kibuye market in the city suburbs and works seven days a week. She buys clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. Jane uses public transportation to go to and from work. She rents her business premises for 40,000 per month and sells retail. Before starting the business, she was a tailor. She sells to an average of ten customers a day and has been in this business for the last fourteen years. Jane has been in MCDT for five years and is now servicing her tenth loan, working all along with the same group mates. Jane wants to use this loan partly to buy more bales of clothing and partly to pay school fees for her children. She also aspires to own a permanent shop for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell and pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Pha's Group

texts.en:
This small loan is made up of four members, all residents in Sarikakeo Commune, Kandal Province. Mr. S. has been selected to be group leader by the group members. He is 29 years old and currently makes a living driving a motorbike taxi. He can earn an average of $3 per day from his business. He presently lives with his wife and his two children. Both of them are single and go to school, while his wife is employed as a garment worker.

To make additional income, S. is applying for a loan as capital to buy a trailer to connect to his existing motorbike and use it to transport fried meatballs to sell.

The other three borrowers are as follows:

S. earns a living by braiding mats for sale and she needs a loan to buy raw materials for her braiding.

S. is a mat maker and she is asking for a loan to buy more raw materials to make the mats for sale.

S. sells foods out of her home. She requests a loan for her husband to buy wood for his carpentry business.

loans.use: To buy a trailer

loans.name: Nkokonjeru-Nalwero Fatuma Group

texts.en:
Fatuma N. (left) is 37 years old. She is a single mother of 2 school-going children. Fatuma is a hard-working and charming business lady. She has 3 years' experience in the retail business. Her shop in Nkokonjeru is stocked with fast-moving consumer goods. Fatuma needs loan funds to replenish her stock of sugar, rice, and flour.

Her dream is to run a general merchandise wholesale shop. The income she earns from her business enables her to care for her children. She hopes that with the expansion of her business, she will be in a position to save money and build a home for her family.

loans.use: Purchase sugar, rice, and flour

loans.name: Habibulla

texts.en:
Habibulla is the son of P. M. and lives in district 9 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single, but as the oldest in the family, he needs to provide all the necessities of his family and pay for all the expenses. 

Habibulla has a car parts shop. He is requesting an individual loan of 50000 Afghani for a term of 12 months to buy tools he needs for his business. He is confident that the loan will enable him to increase his business.

loans.use: To buy tools for his car parts shop

loans.name: Eva Nanziri ‘S Group

texts.en:
Eva is the leader of a five member group. She is 34 years old and the mother of five children who are between the ages of five and twenty. All her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. She resides in and owns a one room house in which two people stay. The rest of her children stay with her mother in the village. They don’t have electricity or piped water at home. The family gets two meals a day and rarely take tea. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.

Eva deals in general merchandise in Kampala city and works seven days a week. She buys shoes from wholesale shops around town. Eva uses public means to go to and from work. She rents her business premises for 80,000 per month and sells on retail. She sells to an average of 17 customers a day and has been in this business for the last five years. She has been in MCDT for three years and is servicing her seventh loan, working all along with the same groupmates. Eva wants to use this loan partly to buy other merchandise and partly to pay school fees for her children She also aspires to build rental houses.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Tila

texts.en:
Muhammad Tila, an educated and married man, has worked in agriculture for more than 10 years. With plenty of land available for cultivation, this hard-working man is requesting a loan to complete his stock, buy more seeds and ready his land for cultivation. Tila is striving for success as a farmer to support his family and help build a better future for his children. He also has a second business, a small café in Jalalabad.

Tila is very happy about this programs of small loans in Jalalabad, Afghanistan. He would like to thank everybody supporting him and hopes to continue his partnership with both Kiva and AFSG in the years to come.

loans.use: Buy seeds and necessary things for his land

loans.name: Unisi Nalumansi  ‘S Group

texts.en:
Unisi is the leader of a five member group. She is 32 years old and married with three children who are between the ages of 11 and 15. All her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. She resides in a rented two-roomed house in which five people stay. They have electricity and piped water at home and the family gets three meals a day. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.

Unisi deals in second-hand shoes in Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She works seven days a week. She also buys these shoes from Owino market. Unisi uses public transport to and from work. She rents her business premises for 60,000 per month and sells on retail. She sells to an average of ten customers a day and to all categories of people. She has been in this business for the last ten years. She has been in MCDT for five years and is servicing her tenth loan, working all along with the same groupmates. Unisi wants this loan to buy more shoes for resale. She also aspires to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for resale.

loans.name: Tarek

texts.en: Tarek is a 26-year-old electrician, living in Bar Elias in the Bekaa Valley. Usually, Tarek works on small projects, especially electrical renovations. Now, he has a new project, he has been asked to prepare an electrical switch board for a generator in his village. He is requesting a loan of $1000 to be able to fulfill this project.

loans.use: Prepare an electrical switch board

loans.name: Moeun's Group

texts.en:
This small loan is being requested by four borrowers, all of whom live in Siem Reap Commune in Kandal Province, Cambodia. The group leader, Mrs. S., is 56 years old and sells vegetables at the Chom Bok Market. She has been selling vegetables since a year ago, and normally earns an income of $4 per day.

She is married and has three children; two of whom are married and the other one is single and employed as a garment worker. Her husband's name is Mr. Neang and he is a taxi driver who provides a service for tourists.

S. hopes to expand her business; thus, she requests a loan to buy various kinds of vegetables for sale. The three other borrowers include S., who is a fish seller and a widow; she needs a loan to buy more fish to sell. S. sells vegetables and she requests a loan to buy vegetables for sale. S. K. sells food and soft drink. She is applying for a loan to enlarge her investment.

loans.use: To buy various kinds of vegetables for sale

loans.name: Nkokonjeru-Mulumba Rehema Group

texts.en:
Rehema M. (right) is 32 years old. She is a hard-working, cooperative and friendly buisnesslady. For 4 years now, Rehema has been in the retail shop business. Due to insufficient capital, she needs a loan to replenish her stock of soap, sugar, rice, and beans. Her profit margin lies at approximately 15% of sales.

Rehema is married with 3 children who are all in school. As a devoted wife, she supports her husband in caring for the family. Her dream is to start up a wholesale shop in Bombo town. Rehema's hope is to have her children graduate from higher institutions of learning someday.

loans.use: Purchase soap, sugar, flour, rice and beans.

loans.name: Samira

texts.en: Samira is a 35-year-old woman who is married, with three children. She and her family live in Al Marej in the Bekaa Valley. Several years ago, Samira started her own shop where she sells all kinds of new and used shoes. Now, Samira wants to borrow $1000 so she can buy more shoes at a very good price.

loans.use: Buy more shoes

loans.name: Berna Babi ‘S Group

texts.en:
Berna is the leader of a five member group. She is 33 years old and married with three children who are between the ages of 10 and 17. All her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house in which five people stay. They have electricity and piped water at home and the family gets three meals a day. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.

Berna owns a poultry farm with about 300 birds and sells eggs to nearby shops. She works seven days a week. She hires a vehicle to buy chicken feed. She sells to an average of twenty customers a day and to all categories of people. Berna has been in this business for the last ten years and has been in MCDT for six years. She is servicing her sixteenth loan, working all along with the same group mates. Agiri wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of chicken feed. She also aspires to own at least 700 birds.

loans.use: To buy more feed for her chickens.

loans.name: Geraida Nakiganda  ‘S Group

texts.en:
Geraida is the leader of a 5-member group. She is a 38-year-old married woman with 5 children aged between 4 and 18. All her children go to school. She takes care of 2 additional family members. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house where she is living with eight people. They have electricity but no piped water at home The family gets three meals a day.

Geraida works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She deals in rice which she buys from farmers and sells both retail and wholesale at her home in Mengo Mackay, which is one of the city suburbs. Geraida works seven days a week and incurs high transport costs She sells to an average of 15 customers a day and sells to all categories of people. She is faced with a challenge in the rainy season, has to deal with transportation which reduces her profits, and the defaulting of her would-be customers.

Geraida has been in this business for the last eight years and has been a member of MCDT for three years, servicing her tenth loan, working all this long time with the same group mates. Geraida’s monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. She wants to use this loan to have a permanent place for her business so that she could sell wholesale only.

loans.use: To have a permanent place for her business

loans.name: Nkokonjeru-Kiiza Halima Group

texts.en:
Halima K. (right) is 37 years old. She is a single mother of 6 children, of whom 3 are in school. For a period of 10 years now, Halima has been selling fruit (sugarcane, jack fruit, mangoes, oranges, etc) and vegetables (cabbages, kale, cowpeas, etc.) Rehema needs a loan to enable her to make advance payments for sugarcane and also purchase sacks of charcoal to add on to her line of businesses.

From her sales, she earns an approximate profit of 18%. The income from the business has kept her family going. However, Halima's dream is to run a general retail shop within her locality. She also hopes to have her children study up to higher institutions (universities and colleges).

loans.use: Advance payment for sugarcane and purchasing sacks of charcoal as a new business

loans.name: Seng's Group

texts.en:
The group of borrowers consists of three people. Its leader, Mrs. H., is 55 years old and sells food to help meet the family's expenses. She sells her foods out of her home and depends on the villagers and passers-by to come to eat. She is married and has three children; all of them are married. One of her children is a garment worker, while her husband works with her selling food.

H. is running her investment well, so that a lot of regular customers recognize the delicious tastes she cooks. H. is applying for a loan as capital to enlarge her investment.

The other two borrowers are:

V., who is a local tailor, and she needs a loan to repair her old house.

S., who is a construction worker. He requests a loan to build a bathroom for the family's hygiene. (S.'s wife appears in the picture because he was not available for photographing.)

The borrowers are people living in Kompong Somnanh Commune in Kandal Province.

loans.use: To enlarge her investment

loans.name: Maimouna

texts.fr:
Maimouna D. a 22 ans, est fiancée, et vit chez ses parents  dans le quartier Darsalam I de la préfecture de koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Très tôt elle abandonna les études pour se consacrer aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat –vente des produits de beauté et diverses autres marchandises. Elle a appris le commerce auprès de sa  maman dépuis son jeune âge. Actuellement elle évolue à son propre compte y’a de cela 2 ans.  Elle est trés bien connue dans le secteur de la cosmétique.  Pour augmenter la taille de son activité et diversifier ses activités, elle décida d’intégrer l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il ya deux mois. Elle est à son 1er prêt en individuel.
Maimouna compte acheter, un important  stock des produits de beauté avec ce prêt.. Elle s’approvisionne auprès des commerçants grossistes de Koutiala et souvent à Bamako(capitale du Mali). Elle vend sur son étale sis au centre du marché de Koko dans la ville de koutiala à une clientèle  constituée essentiellement de femmes , au comptant et à crédit.
 Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30.000FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et préparer son mariage.
Dans ses perspectives, elle envisage d’agrandir son activité jusqu’à  ouvrir une boutique au marché de koko.
texts.en:
Maimouna D. is 22 years old, engaged to be married, and lives in the home of her parents in the Darsalam I district of Koutiala prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Very early on, she abandoned school to devote herself to income-generating work, notably buying and selling beauty products and various other goods. She learned commerce from her mom when she was young. And now, making it on her own for two years, she is very well known in the cosmetics sector. To expand her work and diversify her business, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two months ago. She is on her first individual loan and plans to buy a sizable stock of beauty products with it. She gets her supplies from wholesale merchants of Koutiala and often in Bamako (capital of Mali). From her display at the Koko marketplace in the city of Koutiala, she makes her sales to customers composed essentially of women, cash or credit accepted. Maimouna intends to realize a monthly profit of 30,000 francs CFA that she envisions using to repay the loan interest and to prepare for her marriage. With these prospects, she envisions expanding enough to open a shop at the Koko marketplace.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products for resale

loans.name: Kampala Road-Fatuma Nakka Group

texts.en:
Fatuma N. (front row in the center) is 33 years old. She is married with 3 children, of whom 2 are in school. For a period of 4 years now, Fatuma has been operating a restaurant in Bombo town. Her menu is comprised of local dishes and delicacies. To boost her business, she needs a loan to enable her to purchase more foodstuffs like rice, flour, matooke, and beans.

Her profit margin lies at approximately 30% of sales. Her ambition is to expand her restaurant into a modern one, offering both local and international dishes. Rehema is hard-working and will ensure her children study up to university.

loans.use: Purchase rice, flour, beans, and matooke (a cooking banana)

loans.name: Jihad

texts.en: Jihad is a 37-year-old man who is married, with three children. He and his family live in Harouf, Southern Lebanon. He has owned a small mini-market in his village since 1990. Jihad used his first micro-loan to buy a small fridge to introduce new products into his shop. Today he is asking for a loan of $1000 in order to buy more inventory, so that he can increase his sales.

loans.use: Buy more inventory

loans.name: Mami

texts.fr:
Né vers 1969 à Miéna dans la préfecture de koutiala, Mami  Mallé n’as pas eu la chance de progresser dans les études, alors il embrassa les activités génératrices de révenus. Mami vit avec ses quatre enfants et son épouse chez lui même dans le quartier hamdallaye de la préfecture de koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après s’être essayé à plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus, il décida de se spécialiser dans le commerce des vêtements depuis maintement 10 ans.  IL est trés sollicité lors  des foires hebdomadaires de koutiala ville et des villages environnants.  
Pour diversifier son activité, il décida de faire recours à l ‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il ya deux mois.  IL est à son 1er prêt  individuel..
 Mr Mami  compte acheter différents, modèles et marques de prêt à porter avec cet prêt.. IL s’approvisionne à Lomé ( capitale de la république du Togo ) et il  vend  dans sa boutique sise au grand marché de koutiala et dans les foires hebdomadaires à une clientèle de femmes et d’hommes  au comptant et crédit..
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 140.000FCFA qu’il envisage utiliser pour rembourser les intêrets du prêt et subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Born about 1969 in Miéna in Koutiala prefecture, Mr. Mami Mallé did not have the chance to advance in school, so he embraced working to earn an income. He lives with his four children and wife in his home in the Hamdallaye district in Koutiala prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having tried several kinds of income-generating work, he decided to specialize in the commerce of clothing ten years ago. He is in high demand when it is market day each week in Koutiala City and surrounding villages.

To diversify his business, he decided to turn towards the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two months ago. He is on his first individual loan. With this loan, he plans to buy different styles and brand of ready-to-wear clothing. He gets his supplies in Lomé (capital of the Republic of Togo) and sells them, cash or credit accepted, in his shop, located at the grand marketplace of Koutiala, and in the weekly markets. His customers are composed of women and men.

He intends to realize a monthly profit of 140,000 francs CFA that he envisions using for repaying the loan interest and to providing for his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ready-to-wear clothing

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 46-year-old man who is married, with six children. He and his family live in Twayte, in the Bekaa Valley. Ahmad has owned a mini-market since 2002, where he serves his small village. Ahmad is requesting a loan of $1000 in order to increase his inventory, and his income.

loans.use: Buy Inventory

loans.name: Nusratullo

texts.ru: Сохибов Нусратулло житель района Гиссар. Возраст 31 год , женат и имеет троих детей. Уже 10 лет занимается торговлей. торгует коврами. Торговая точка находится на центральном рынке района.н арендует свою торговую точку. Кредит планирует получить для того .чтобы оплатить аренду за длительный срок. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 9 месяцев.
texts.en:
Nusratullo S. lives in the Gissar region. He is 31 years old, married and has three children. He has been in the retail business selling rugs for ten years. He has a vendor spot on the region's central market, which he rents. He plans to get a loan to pay the rent for several months ahead. The plans to pay off the loan within 9 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay rent

loans.name: Lukia Nassuna ‘S Group

texts.en:
Lukia is the leader of a four member group. She is 57 years old and the mother of five children between the ages of 19 and 37. Two of her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. She resides in a four roomed house that she owns in which four people stay. They have electricity and piped water at home and the family gets three meals a day. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.

Lukia deals in ladies shoes on William street in Kampala city and works seven days a week. She buys these shoes from wholesale shops around town. Lukia uses public means to go to and from work. She rents her business premises for 100,000 per month and sells retail and wholesale. Lukia sells to an average of 15 customers a day and has been in this business for the last fifteen years. Lukia is servicing her sixteenth loan, working all along with the same groupmates. She wants to use this loan to starting buying directly from Nairobi. She also aspires to build rental houses.

loans.use: To start buying her goods from Nairobi.

loans.name: Ismatullo

texts.ru: Мирзоев Исматулло живет в Гиссарском районе. Возраст 32 года , женат и имеет троих детей. Имеет высшее образование. По специальности журналист. Но по профессии не работает. Для того ,чтобы обеспечить свою семью занялся бизнесом. Торгует коврами на центральном рынке. Товар привозит из Ирана. Кредит планирует получить для, того , чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 9 месяцев.
texts.en:
Ismatullo M. lives in the Gissar region. He is 32 years old, married and has three children. He has high education and has a degree in journalism. He does not work by his profession. To be able to support his family he started his own business. He sells rugs on the central market which he brings in from Iran. He plans to use the loan to increase the circulation of his goods. He will pay off the loan within 9 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase circulation

loans.name: Seang's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers was established by three people who live in Prek Tmey Commune in Kandal Province. Its leader, Mrs. Y., was born 1955. She is earning money by selling flowers for beer gardens and other ceremonies. She grows the flowers from her home and sometimes buys them from a market seller.

She is married with two children, one of whom is married and the other one is single and employed. Her husband is a local construction worker. Y. works hard at her business activities every day and never wastes time. In order to expand the business, Y. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer to use for growing flowers, and to buy some flowers from the market to sell.

The other two borrowers are:

M., who is a flower seller, and she requests a loan to purchase more flowers for sale.

S., who sells a few groceries from home. She is applying for a loan to buy more grocery inventory for sale.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to use for growing flowers

loans.name: Hasfa Nakku ‘S Group

texts.en:
Hasfa is the leader of a four member group. She is a 35 year old mother of four children who are between the ages for five and eleven. All her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in a rented two-roomed house in which four people stay. They have electricity and piped water at home and the family gets three meals a day. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.

Hasfa sells sugar cane in Kalerwe market and works seven days a week. She buys the sugar cane from Kawolo, one of the villages where sugar cane is mostly grown. She uses private means to go to and from Kawolo. She sells both on retail and wholesale to an average of 15 customers a day and has been in this business for 10 years. Hasfa is servicing her fourteenth loan, working all along with the same groupmates. She wants to use this loan to start buying a full lorry of sugar canes.

loans.use: To start buying a full lorry of sugar canes to sell.

loans.name: Benkafo(Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes de Benkafo sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 47ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Koumantou préfecture de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Ce groupe fait essentiellement des activités diverses et variées : (restauration, habillement…)              
Elles sont partenaires de Soro Yiriwaso depuis trois ans et sont à leur sixième prêt. Selon la présidente ce partenariat est très important car cela leurs permet d’avoir un capital permanent pour mener des activités génératrices de revenus.
Le présent prêt permettra d’acheter 10 kg de poisson frais par jour à 650 FCFA le kg, 5 litres d’huile alimentaire et du bois de chauffe. Ce poisson sera frit et vendu. Ce commerce permet de gagner 200 Fcfa sur chaque kg de poisson vendu. Elles effectuent leurs ventes de façon fixe au marché et de façon ambulante dans les différents quartiers de Koumantou en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes. 
Les vendeuses de tissus achètent 10 pièces de tissus wax à Bamako(capitale du Mali). Les tissus wax sont découpés en « 3 pagnes » puis vendus. Les tissus bazin sont vendus par mètre. Les commerçantes gagnent 250 FCFA sur chaque « 3 pagnes » vendu et 500 FCFA sur chaque mètre de bazin vendu.
Les membres de Benkafo peuvent  réaliser en moyenne 30.000 à 45.000FCFA par mois. Cela suffit pour rembourser le prêt et faire face à certaines dépenses de la famille. 
A l’avenir les membres de Benkafo veulent avoir leurs propres boutiques afin de devenir des grossistes en commerce de poisson frais et de tissus demandés par la clientèle.
texts.en:
The women of the group Benkafo are all married and average 47 years of age and four children. They live in traditional extended families in the village of Koumantou (in Bougouni prefecture, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). This group essentially does a variety and diversity of work: catering, clothing, ...

The group members have been partners of Soro Yiriwaso for three years and are on their sixth loan. According to the president, this partnership is very important because it enables them to have continuous capital for working in income-generating businesses. The current loan is enough to buy 10 kg of fresh fish each day at 650 francs CFA per kilo, 5 liters of cooking oil, and some firewood. The fish will be fried and offered for sale. This commerce allows them to earn 200 francs per kilo of fish sold. The group members make their sales from a fixed location at the marketplace and door-to-door in the different districts of Koumantou, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed generally of women.

The members who sell cloth will buy 10 lengths of Wax brand cloth in Bamako (capital of Mali). This cloth is cut up into three "pagnes" (each typically about 1 meter by 3 meters in size) which are then sold. Damask fabric is sold by the meter. The merchants earn 250 francs from each pagne sold and 500 francs from each meter of damask sold.

The group members can realize an average of 30,000 to 45,000 francs per month. This is enough to repay the loan and to address certain family expenses. In the future, the group members want to have their own shops in order to become wholesalers of the fresh fish and cloth that customers demand.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish and cloth

loans.name: Naut

texts.en:
Naut S., 33, is married and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She grows rice and raises pigs to earn a living, and is able to make US$2 each day. Her husband, Mao Thy, 36, is a salesman in a busy market, selling various kinds of plates and rice. He makes an average of US$7 per day. The has three children, two of whom are students while the third is too young to attend school.

Mrs. Naut S. is requesting a loan to purchase more land to expand her farming.

loans.use: To purchase land for farming.

loans.name: Kampala Road-Sharifa Namusoke Group

texts.en:
Sharifa N. (2nd right) is 38 years old. She has 3 years experience in snack-making. Sharifa is popular in Bombo town for her mouth-watering pancakes, samosas, and cassava chips. Her business earns her a profit margin of 20% of sales.

Sharifa needs a loan to purchase cassava, wheat flour, millet flour, peas, cooking oil, and charcoal. Her dream is to run a retail shop. She is married with 4 children, all of them in school. She therefore hopes to educate her children up through university.

loans.use: Purchase cassava, wheat flour, millet flour, peas, cooking oil and charcoal.

loans.name: Elizabeth Fumilayo

texts.en: Elizabeth Fumilayo J. sells vegetables like carrots, cabbage, etc. She has been in this business for a long time. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more vegetables to sell. Elizabeth lives in Ibadan, Nigeria. She is 40 years old and married with 3 children. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Kheng

texts.en: Kheng S. is 41 years old and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province. She raises pigs and sells rice noodles to earn a living, and is able to make around $2 each day. Her husband is a rice farmer and construction worker in their village, making on average $3 a day. This couple has four children, one who is employed as a garment worker and one who is a student. Mrs. Kheng S. would like to take out a loan of $600 to purchase a cow to help her plow her farmland.

loans.use: To purchase cow.

loans.name: Ngeb

texts.en:
Ngeb K. is 65 years old and lives with her husband and nine children in Kampong Cham province. She works in a grocery store and cooks and sells her food on the roadside in her village, earning about US$1 profit each day. Her husband is a rice farmer making less than a dollar a day on average. The couple is also supported by two of their children who work as garment factory workers and construction workers.

Mrs. Ngeb K. would like to take out a loan of US$300 to expand her grocery store by adding more items to meet her clients' demand.

loans.use: To expand her grocery store.

loans.name: Choeurn

texts.en:
Choeurn R. is 52 years old and is a rice farmer. Her husband is a village chief who earns a salary of $40 per month. Choeurn R. and her husband have eight children; four are married and no longer live at home, while two are employed as garment factory workers and two others are students.

Choeurn R. is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase a motorbike for her family’s transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en:
Khaled is 23 years old and lives in Saida, in southern Lebanon. He has been working as a taxi driver for a year. His clients are his friends, neighbors, and others. When he first started his business, he didn’t have much start-up capital, which made it hard for him to purchase a car. He decided to start his business because he always wanted to be independent in his work.

Khaled has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his car. This is the first time that Khaled has requested a loan.

loans.use: To perform maintenance on his car

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To rent farmland to grow bean and rice.

loans.name: Walid

texts.en:
Walid is 43 years old and lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Walid has been working as a salesman for eleven years. He has requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise to sell.

Walid has been a microcredit client for five years now and has always paid on time. His previous loans have influenced his work as well as his life in a good way. Thanks to his loans, he was able to expand his business and improve his family's situation. Walid is speciA. in his work because he has a good relationship with his clients. In the future, he plans to purchase a van in order to facilitate his work.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Nabi

texts.ru: Мирзоев Наби житель Гиссарского района. Возраст 58 лет, женат и имеет двоих детей. По профессии водитель. Но занимается бизнесом. Торгует коврами  из Ирана. Кредит планирует использовать в течение 9 месяцев. Опыт в бизнесе уже 33 года. Дело приносит неплохой доход. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 9 месяцев.
texts.en:
Nabi M. lives in Gissar region. He is 58 years old and is married with two children. He is a driver by training but he makes a living by selling Persian carpets. He has 33 years of business experience. His business is quite profitable, and Nabi plans to pay off the loan within 9 months.

Translated from Russian by Oksana Buranbaeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase cash flow

loans.name: Mpakawero Lufula-Nasimbwa Sarah Group

texts.en:
N. Sarah (front left) is 42 years old. She has three years of experience in selling fish. Sarah purchases a variety of fish, such as tilapia, Nile perch and silver fish, from the famous Gabba market on the shores of Lake Victoria in Kampala. Her average profit from her sales is approximately 20%.

Sarah needs a loan to replenish her stock of fish. Her main dream is to set up a brick making factory in Bombo. She is a widow with five children who are all independent. Hardworking Sarah takes care of five of her grandchildren.

loans.use: Purchase more fish.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is 31 years old and lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon. Ahmad has been washing and cleaning cars for ten years. He has also been selling car cleaning products. Ahmad requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a handspike for his business. This is his second loan, and he has always paid on time.

His previous loan influenced his business in a good way because it let him improve his work. Ahmad is special in his work because he uses good cleaning products for the cars and he also does a good cleaning work. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase a handspike for his car cleaning business.

loans.name: Scholastica Naggita ‘S Group

texts.en:
Scholastica is the leader of a four member group. She is 58 years old and married with six children. None of her children, who are between the ages of 28 and 38, go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in a three-roomed house that she owns in which five people stay. They have electricity and piped water at home and the family gets three meals a day. She works in a semi-urban area in Kampala city centre.

Scholastica sells domestic products in Kikuubo, one of busiest places in Kampala. She works six days a week and rents her business premises for 100,000 per month. She sells to an average of ten customers a day and to all categories of people. She sells retail and wholesale and has been in this business for the last three years. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees. She is faced with high commodity prices, which chase away some of her long time customers.

Scholastica has been in MCDT for six years and is servicing her fifteenth loan, working all along with the same groupmates. She wants to use this loan to acquire a bigger place for her business and also aspires to own a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To acquire a bigger place for her retail business.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok S., 47, is married and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She and her husband make and sell brooms in the local market. On average, they make a total of US$4 profit each day. The couple has four children, two who are students, one who is a garment worker and a fourth who is a farmer. Mrs. Sok S. would like to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike to transport brooms to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Dalal

texts.en:
Dalal is 53 years old and lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with her husband. Dalal has been selling beauty products from her house since 2004. She sells makeup, cosmetics, perfumes, creams and accessories. Dalal requested a loan of 700 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her business. This is her third loan, and she has always paid on time.

Thanks to her previous loans, Dalal was able to improve her business and purchase more merchandise to satisfy the needs of her clients. Dalal is special in her work because she sells nice products and she knows how to please her clients. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. Dalal decided to open her business because she wanted to help her husband by supplementing the family's income. In the future, she plans to expand her business by purchasing more merchandise.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Thai's Group

texts.en:
There are four members applying for this loan, all of whom live in Prek Compeus Commune in Kandal Province. The group leader, Mrs. S., aged 37, makes a living selling both fish and vegetables in the local market. She is married and currently has four children; two of them are single and the other two are married and live away from the family home. Her husband's name is Tem Khoeun, 47, and he is a local building worker. The couple can earn an income of approximately $10 a day to support their family's living conditions.

S.'s business is going well, and in order to make the business more successful and generate a stable income for the family, she is asking for a loan to buy more fish and vegetables for sale.

The other three borrowers are:

P., who is a Cambodian garment worker, and she is applying for a loan to repair her old house.

S., who is a widow and sells vegetables. She is asking for a loan to purchase different kinds of vegetables for sale.

C., who is a vegetable seller and a widow. She requests a loan as capital to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish and vegetables for sale

loans.name: An

texts.en: An S. is a professional tailor and makes approximately US$3 every day. She is 28 years old and lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband and two of her children. She runs a small tailoring shop with her sister, while her husband is a construction foreman making about US$4 a day. An S. will use this loan to purchase another sewing machine to expand her shop.

loans.use: To purchase sewing machine.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Pov E. is 46 years old and lives with her husband and two of her childrE. in the Kampong Cham province. She makes and sells rice noodles in her village and earns about US$7 every day. Her husband, pictured here, is a rice farmer and makes about US$2 a day. The couple also receives support from their two childrE. who work as garment factory workers. Pov E. would like to use this loan to purchase a motorbike for her childrE. to commute to work. This will reduce the amount of money that they spend on public transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Yankadi (Bon Endroit) Group

texts.fr:
Ayant une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et 4 enfants, les membres de Yankadi  vivent  dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec beaux parents, frères et souers dans le village de Koumantou préfecture de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Les femmes du groupe Yankadi font diverses activités génératrices de revenus qui vont la petite restauration à la vente de condiments alimentaires sans oublier quelques fois les fruits et légumes
Ces femmes sont partenaires de Soro Yiriwaso  depuis 2 ans .Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt .Tous les prêts  précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau  prêt elles veulent acheter, des condiments alimentaires en  provenance de Sikasso pendant les jours de foire. Sur chaque kg de choux et  d’oignon vendu, elles gagnent 50 FCFA ; chaque kg de poisson séché vendu rapporte 250FCFA.
Les vendeuses de gâteaux achètent un sac de 25 kg de  farine de blé, du beurre de karité et de la levure pour la préparation du gâteau. Elles préparent 5 kg de farine tous les mercredi, jour de foire pour la vente.
Les membres de Yankadi réalisent en   moyenne une marge bénéficiaire de 30.000FCFA par mois. Ce qui leurs permet de rembourser l’échéance du prêt et subvenir à certains besoins du foyer (santé, éducation, habillement…etc.)
En perspectives chacune de ces femmes veut devenir grossiste dans le commerce de condiments, de farine de blé et d’autres articles demandés par la population locale.
texts.en:
With an average age of 30 and four children, the members of Yankadi come from traditional extended families with in-laws, brothers and sisters in Koumantou villlage in Bougouni prefecture (the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women of Yankadi are involved in a variety of income-generating activities ranging from small restaurants to selling seasonings, not to mention occasionally selling fruit and vegetables. The women have been Soro Yiriwaso partners for the last two years and they are on their fourth loan. All of the previous loans were successfully repaid. With this new loan they would like to buy seasonings from Sikasso on market day. They make a 50 Franc CFA profit on every kilogram of onions sold; each kilogram of fish sold brings in 250 Francs CFA. The cake saleswomen buy a 25 kilogram bag of wheat flour, as well as shea butter and yeast to make their baked goods. They use five kilograms of flour each Wednesday, market day, for sales. The members of Yankadi make an average profit of 30,000 Francs CFA per month. This allows them to reimburse their loan and meet certain household needs (health, education, clothing, etc). In the future each of these women would like to become a wholesaler of seasonings, wheat flour, and other items popular with the local population.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seasonings and ingredients for baked goods

loans.name: Yinka

texts.en: Yinka O. sells sarongs. She started this business in 2000. She is 32 years old and married with 3 children. She lives in Ibadan, Nigeria. She hopes to expand her sarong business. She needs the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Khin

texts.en: Khin S., 32, is a rice farmer who lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband. She has been a rice farmer since 1980 and is able to make about US$2 each day. Her husband, Kek Pheap, 35, pictured here, is a horse-cart driver. He transports goods and people to earn approximately US$6 a day. The couple has one young child. Mrs. Khin S. would like to use a loan of US$700 to purchase a bigger and healthier horse for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase horse.

loans.name: Nguon

texts.en:
Nguon M., 30, is married and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She grows bananas and sells them in the village market, earning approximately US$3.50 each day. Her husband is a horse-cart driver who makes around US$11 each day. This couple has three children, one of whom attends school.

Mrs. Nguon M. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to make two investments. She will use US$500 to buy a bigger and healthier horse for her husband, and she will use the rest to rent a banana farm.

loans.use: To purchase a horse and rent a banana farm.

loans.name: Yetunde

texts.en: Yetunde A. is 36 years old and married with 3 children. She and her family live in Ibadan, Nigeria. She sells clothes and shoes. She has been in this business since 2000. She needs the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more clothes and shoes to sell. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Malika

texts.ru: Джурабоева Малика жительница Гиссарского района. Возраст 34 года , не замужем . Воспитывает сына одна. Имеет высшее образование и работает учителем в средней школе. Кроме того занимается бизнесом, так как ей приходится много работать для того, чтобы дать ребенку все необходимое. Торгует коврами. Кредит планирует использовать для того, чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 6 месяцев.
texts.en:
Malika D. lives in the Gissar region. She is 34 years old, not married and is raising a son on her own. She has university education and works as a teacher in junior high school. In addition she runs a business selling carpets. She works long hours so as to provide for all her son's needs. Malika plans to use the loan to increase sales. She will be able to repay the loan within 6 months.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Nut

texts.en:
Nut V., 46, is pictured here with her husband. The couple lives in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. Mrs. Nut V. grows rice, earning a profit of less than one dollar each day. Her husband owns a big grinding machine that he uses to serve the local farmers, earning US$2.30 per day. The couple has four children: three are students and one is married and no longer lives at home.

Mrs. Nut V. would like to use this loan to purchase a motorbike and a trailer for her husband so he can transport goods to earn additional income.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle taxi.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’age de 26 ans et de 3 enfants. Elles vivent   généralement dans de familles conjugales nucléaires. Elles résident à Sokoura-Est l’un des quartiers  de la ville de la préfecture de Dioïla (une des préfectures de la deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali, Koulikoro). .
Par des relations de commerce ses femmes se sont connues et font essentiellement de l’habillement comme activité principale.
 Dans le souci de fructifier leur activité elles ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur cinquième prêt. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles comptent acheter, 100 pièces de pagnes à Bamako (capitale du Mali) auprès des grossistes. Ces pagnes seront découpés en trois pagnes  vendus au comptant et à crédit sur le marché de Dioïla à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent obtenir avec ce prêt un bénéfice de 50 000 FCFA  chacune et se projettent d’utiliser cet intérêt pour les frais de santé et d’éducation des enfants.
texts.en:
The women of Benkadi group are all married and on average 26-years old with three children. Most live with their immediate marital families. Their homes are in Sokoura-East, one of the neighborhoods of Dioïla (one of the prefectures of Koulikoro, the second-largest administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women got to know each other through business relationships built around selling clothing, which is their main activity. Intending to strengthen their businesses, the women decided to become part of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their fifth loan. All of the previous loans were successfully repaid. They are planning to buy 100 bolts of fabric from Bamako (the Malian capital) from wholesalers. The bolts of fabric will be cut into three sections and sold on credit in Dioïla's market to customers including both men and women. They plan to make a profit of 50,000 Francs CFA from this loan and each one envisions using this money for health and education costs for their children.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric

loans.name: Chhim

texts.en:
Chhim S. is 56 years old and lives with her three children, who are employed as garment factory workers

Mrs. Chhim S. has been raising fish in the Kampong Cham province for two years. She has a big pond and makes about US$12.50 each day. She is asking for a loan to breed more fish.

loans.use: To breed more fish.

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.ru: Шарипов Мухаббат проживает в районе Гиссар. Возраст 37 лет, незамужем и имеет троих детей. Работает педагогом в средней школе. Но после того как она осталась одна с тремя детьми на руках ей пришлось заняться бизнесом. Торгует коврами на центральном рынке Гиссара. Кредит планирует использовать для того, чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 6 месяцев.
texts.en:
Muhabbat S. lives in the Gissar region. She is 37 years old, not married and has three children. She works as a teacher in junior high school. After she was left alone with 3 children she had to go into business to support them. Muhabbat sells carpets at the central market in Gissar. She plans to use the loan to increase sales. She will repay her loan in 6 months.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Khin

texts.en: Khin L., 39, is married and lives with three of her children in the province of Kampong Cham. She and her husband work together as duck breeders. Together they make around US$5 each day. Three of their children are students and help raising the ducks as well. Mrs. Khin L. would like to take out a loan to breed more ducks and purchase feed for them.

loans.use: To buy more ducks to breed and feed for them.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary O. sells provisions and drinks. She is married and lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is requesting the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Gairatmurod

texts.ru: Джурабоев Гайратмурод житель Гиссарского района.Возраст 32 года . Женат и имеет четверых детей. Имеет высшее образование , работает директором в средней школе района. Кроме того  имеет дополнительный доход. Занимается торговлей крупно рогатого скота. Опыт в данном бизнесе составляет 10 лет. Планирует получить кредит сроком на 6 месяцев. А использовать его для того, чтобы купить бычка.
texts.en:
Gairatmurod D. lives in the Gissar region. He is 32 years old, married with 4 children. He has a university education and is a director of a junior high school in Gissar. He supplements his income by selling livestock. He has been doing this for 10 years. He wants to use the loan to buy a young bull and plans to repay it within 6 months.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a young bull

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
En  majorité des femmes mariées, les membres du groupe Sabougnouma de l’association Djiguiya de Sokoura Nord ont une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans et de 2 enfants .Elles vivent  dans de familles conjugales nucléaires dans la ville de Dioïla chef lieu de préfecture relevant de la  Région  de  Koulikoro en République du Mali.
 Elles se sont rencontrées par des relations commerciales et font essentiellement de la restauration comme activité principale
Dans le souci de développer leur activité génératrice de revenus, ces femmes ont intégrés l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur sixième prêt. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
 Les membres du groupe comptent acheter, 500kg de riz, 300kg de maïs, 200kg de fonio et une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires. 
Tous ces produits ci-dessus cités seront achetés sur place au marché de Dioïla. Ces céréales servent aux femmes à faire de plats délicieux  très convoités par la population de Dioïla. Elles comptent obtenir un bénéfice de 30 000 FCFA  chacune et se proposent d’utiliser cet intérêt dans l’entretien des enfants.
texts.en:
Mostly married women, the member of the Sabougnouma of the association Djiguiya de Sokoura Nord average 26 years of age and two children. They live in nuclear families in the city of Dioïla, the seat of the prefecture within the Koulikoro region in the Republic of Mali. The women know one another through commerce and as their principal business essentially make meals to sell.

Concerned about developing their income-generating work, they joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their sixth loan. All the previous loans have been correctly repaid. They intend to buy 500 kg of rice, 300 kg of corn, 200 kg of fonio (a type of millet), and a large quantity of condiments.

All these goods cited above will be purchased locally at the Dioïla marketplace. The grains are used by the women to make delicious dishes that are much coveted by the people of Dioïla. Each group member plans to make a profit of 30,000 francs CFA and intend to use this interest to care for the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Catering

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en: Sunday O. is 49 years old and married with 5 children. He sells books. He loves this business and hopes to expand his business. He needs the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more books to sell. He says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more books to sell

loans.name: Dasola

texts.en: Dasola A. is 32 years old and married with 3 children. She sells drinks and pepper soup. She makes a lot of profit from this business. She needs the loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Turamurod

texts.ru: Шомуродов Турамурод житель Гиссарского района. Возраст 58 лет. Женат и имеет 6 детей. Имеет среднеспециальное образование. Работает водителем частного такси. Планирует получить кредитдлоя того, чтобы сделать ремонт своей автомашины.Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Turamurod S. lives in the Gissar region. He is 58 years old, married and has 6 children. He has a college level education and works as taxi driver. He is requesting a loan to repair and service his car. He will repay the loan in 12 months. Шомуродов Турамурод житель Гиссарского района. Возраст 58 лет. Женат и имеет 6 детей. Имеет среднеспециальное образование. Работает водителем частного такси. Планирует получить кредитдлоя того, чтобы сделать ремонт своей автомашины.Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Car service and repair

loans.name: Sebedo (C’Est Du Serieux) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sebedo sont tous des femmes mariées dont la moyenne d’âge est de 33 ans et de 6 enfants .Elles vivent  dans de familles conjugales élargies traditionnelles dans le village de Timpana relevant de la préfecture de Dioïla  Région  de  Koulikoro République du Mali..
Elles se sont connues par des relations de voisinage, et professionnelles. Ces femmes se sont spécialisées dans l’achat vente du lait frais de vache.
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur quatrième prêt. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Les membres du groupe comptent acheter  1000 litres de lait auprès des éleveurs de Timpana et ses environs. Le lait ainsi acheté est vendu frais, et le reste  est transformé et  vendu en lait caillé, une partie transformée en beurre etc. sur le marché de Massigui et Dioïla à une clientèle venant des grandes villes et à la population locale. 
Si tout se passe normalement elles espèrent obtenir 40 000FCFA de bénéfice avec ce prêt et compte utiliser ce bénéfice dans l’entretien des animaux qu’elles viennent d’acheter en vu de les élever.
texts.en:
The members of the group Sebedo are all married woman who average 33 years of age and six children. They live in traditional extended families in the village of Timpana belonging to Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali. They all know one another through ties of community and profession. These women became specialized in buying and selling of fresh cow’s milk.

Concerned about satisfying their customers, they decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their fourth loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

The group members plan to buy 1,000 liters of milk from farmers of Timpana and surrounding areas. Such milk is sold fresh, and the rest is processed and sold curdled, or made into butter, etc. Sales are made at the marketplaces of Massigui et Dioïla to customers from large cities and to local people. If everything occurs normally, they hope to obtain 40,000 francs CFA of profit with this loan and plan to use it for maintaining the animals they just bought for raising as livestock.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy milk

loans.name: Olanike Morenekeji

texts.en: Olanike Morenekeji O. is 40 years old and married with 3 children. She lives in Ibadan, Nigeria. She has a catering service for various ceremonies like marriages, birthdays, etc. She needs the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more catering materials. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more catering materials

loans.name: Dilshod

texts.ru: Шомуродов Дильшод житель Гиссарского района. Возраст 27 лет, женат . Пока детей не имеет. По профессии шофер. Работает водителем маршрутного такси. Имеет автомашину марки "Газель".Его дело приносит неплохой доход , но в данный момент он должен произвести капитальный ремонт автомашины. Поэтому он решил получить кредит сроком на 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Dilshod S. lives in the Gissar region. He is 27 years old, married and does not yet have any children. He works as a taxi driver and owns a 'Gazelle' make of car. His business makes a decent profit but at the moment he needs to have a big auto-service done on the car. He plans to use the loan for this service and to repay it in 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Car service and repair

loans.name: Siguitemasson Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Siguitemasson sont toutes  mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans et de 4 enfants. Elles vivent  dans de familles conjugales élargies traditionnelles avec leurs coépouses, sœurs, et enfants dans le village de Timpana relevant de la préfecture de Dioïla et de la Région  de  Koulikoro en République du Mali.
 Elles se sont connues par les relations de mariages. Dans le souci  d’améliorer leur commerce ces femmes ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur quatrième prêt. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter,  4 tonnes de maïs, 2 tonnes de sorgho et 500 kg de fonio auprès des paysans producteurs. Elles s’approvisionnent dans le village de Timpana et ses environnants pour ensuite les revendre en détail et en gros sur le marché de Dioïla à des revendeurs venant des grandes villes. 
Elles comptent obtenir un bénéfice de 50 000 FCFA et se bénéfice sera utilisé pour appuyer les époux à surmonter les dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The women of the Siguitemasson group are all married and average 28 years of age and four children. They live in large traditional families with their co-wives, sisters and children in the village of Timpana, prefecture of Dioïla in the region of Koulikoro in Mali. They know one another as they are related by marriage. They want to improve their busineses, and so these women decided to join the microfinancial institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their fourth loan. All their previous loans have been repaid. They will use this loan to buy four tons of maize, two tons of sorghum and 500 kg of "fonio" (a type of cereal) from farmers. They buy their goods in and around the village of Timpana to resell at the market of Dioïla to retailers who come from larger cities.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Lola

texts.en: Lola B. is 44 years old and married with 2 children. She lives in Ibadan, Nigeria. She sells wine. She started this business in 2000. She needs the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more wine to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more wine to sell

loans.name: Laide

texts.en: Laide E. lives in Ibadan, Nigeria. She is 42 years old and married with 4 children. She sells medicine. The demands for her medicine are high, and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She needs the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more medicine to sell. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Opeyemi

texts.en: Opeyemi O. is 30 years old and married without a child. He lives in Ibadan, Nigeria. He sells electronics. He started this business in 2005. He needs the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more electronics to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics to sell

loans.name: Hawa

texts.fr:
Madame Hawa Dembélé est âgée de 51 ans, mariée elle vit avec son mari et ses 7 enfants  dans une famille nucléaire dans le quartier Darsalam de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Comme beaucoup de femmes au Mali, elle n’as pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école et était obligée d’embrancher une activité génératrice de revenus dès son jeune age. Après beaucoup d’échecs, elle décida de fabriquer et de vendre des boissons locales non alcoolisées depuis trois ans. Elle  jouit d’une grande  clientèle et  notoriété. 
En relation  avec le programme il y’ trois ans, elle  bénéficia de trois prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) et d’un prêt individuel avec Soro Yiriwaso tous remboursés correctement. Elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel et compte l’utiliser pour acheter, 3 sacs de sucres, 1 moteur de réfrigérateur et 2 cartons de poudre de jus. Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières sur place à Ségou. Madame Hawa Dembélé vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 45 000FCFA. qui servira à  payer intérêts du prêt et les frais scolaires des enfants. Son ambition est de diversifier son activité en embrassant la vente de calebasses.
texts.en:
Hawa Dembélé is 51 years old, married and lives with her husband and seven children in a nuclear family in the neighbourhood of Darsalam in Ségou, Mali. Like many women in Mali, she never had the opportunity to attend school and was made to earn money from a young age. After a number of failures, she decided to prepare and sell local non-alcoholic drinks three years ago. She has many customers and is well known. She joined the program three years ago and has received three group loans and one individual loan from Soro Yiriwaso. She has fully repaid all previous loans. This is her second individual loan and she will use it to buy three bags of sugar, a motor for her refrigerator and two cartons of powdered juice. She buys her ingredients locally in Ségou. Hawa Dembélé sells both for cash and on credit to her customers, men and women. She expects to make a monthly profit of 45,000 FCFA which she will use to pay the interest on the loan and her children's tuition. Her goal is to diversify her business by selling calabashes.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make non-alcoholic drinks.

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
K. Farida is 29 years old, married and has one child. Farida has been selling clothing for children for the past 3 years. She started this business because her husband has no fixed job and sometimes they had difficulties in their lives. Using her savings, she started to travel to the neighboring town of Istaravshan to buy clothing to sell at the local market of Isfara. Little by little she increased the number of clients and expanded her business. Nevertheless, presently her selection of garments is poor and therefore she requests a loan of 2500 Somoni to be repaid in 6 months. With this loan Farida can purchase new and varied merchandise to offer her clients. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was a key post along the Silk Road and is where the rule of Alexander the Great ended. It is famous for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase children's clothing for resale

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame  Aminata   K. est âgée de 21 ans, mariée elle vit avec son mari et ses 2 enfants  dans une grande  famille traditionnelle avec plusieurs autres ménages dans le quartier Ségou Bougouni Lafiabougou de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Dès son jeune âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus auprès d’une voisine du quartier qui vendait des habits. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage avec cette dernière, depuis 4 ans elle exerce à son propre compte la vente d’habits, de  couvertures et des draps de lits au marché Château. Elle  jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. Sa force de vente est due à son prix abordable et à  la qualité de ses  habits. 
Dans le souci de pérenniser son activité et d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elle est en relation  3 ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires et 1 prêt individuel tous bien remboursés, il est à son 2ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter 5 pièces de pagnes Wax, 5 complets de couvertures draps, 5 complets pour habits d’enfants. Elle s’approvisionne auprès des grossistes  à Bamako (capitale du Mali). Madame Aminata   vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000FCFA, qui va lui  permettre de renouveler son stock de marchandises et d’aider son mari à  prendre en charge la famille. Son ambition est d’avoir une maison.
texts.en:
Ms. Aminata K., age 21, is married and lives with her husband and two children in a large traditional family with several other households in the Ségou Bougouni Lafiabougou district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). From an early age, she started working to earn an income with a neighbor who used to sell clothing. After several years of apprenticeship with her, Aminata has been working on her own for four years selling clothing, blankets, and bed sheets at the Château marketplace. She enjoys a large customer base and distinction. Her strong sales are due to her affordable prices and the quality of her clothing.

Concerned about ensuring continued work and to increase her sales figures, she has turned towards the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, which has had an association with her for three years. After four solidarity loans and one individual loan, all repaid, she is on her second individual loan, which will be used to buy 5 lengths of Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth of good quality), 5 sets of blankets and sheets, and 5 children's outfits. She gets her supplies from wholesalers in Bamako (capital of Mali) and sell to customers composed of men and women, cash or credit accepted.

She intends to realize a monthly profit of 70,000 francs CFA that will enable her to replenish her stock of merchandise and to help her husband support the family. Her ambition is to have a house.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing, blankets, and bed sheets

loans.name: Katende Nulu‘S Group

texts.en:
Nulu is the leader of a four member group. She is 30 years old and married with four children. All her children, who are between the ages 4 and 12, go to school. She also takes care of her old parents. She resides in a rented two-roomed house in which eight people stay. They don’t have electricity or piped water at home. The family gets two meals a day.

Nulu works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She sells charcoal at her home in Mengo Mackay, which is one of the city suburbs. She works seven days a week and has no transport costs. She sells to an average of 30 customers a day and to all categories of people. She is faced with the challenge of the rainy season and defaulting on her would-be customers.

Nulu has been in this business for the last seven years and has been in MCDT for four years. She is servicing her second loan, working all along with the same groupmates. Nulu‘s monthly expenses include rent and feeding the family. She wants to use this loan to buy a more sacks of charcoal.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Nazira

texts.ru: Миногова Назира жительница города Турсун-Заде. Возраст 45 лет, замужем и имеет троих детей. Имеет среднеспециальное образование. Работает медсестрой в поликлинике города. Кроме того имеет участок земли , которую засеивает пшеницей. Кредит планирует получить и использовать для покупки зерна. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Nazira M. lives in the town of Tursun-Zade. She is 45 years old, married and has 3 children. She has college level education and works as a nurse at a clinic in town. In addition to the job she has a plot of land that she farms wheat on. Nazira plans to use the loan to buy wheat seed grain. She will repay her loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wheat  seed grain

loans.name: Uguljon

texts.en:
N. Uguljon is 41 years old. She and her husband, a furniture-maker, have raised 3 children. Uguljon sells clothing for children such as knitted jackets, sweaters, jeans, socks etc. She has been in this business for 8 years. As a rule Uguljon travels to the neighboring town of Istaravshan every week to purchase new goods. She tries to choose a variety of items of good quality and attractive prices which allows her to keep her clientele. Her daughter, who is pictured in the photo, helps her with the business. Today Uguljon is requesting a loan of $1200 US for the term of 9 months. In February she is planning to make her next trip to Istaravshan. She’ll spend the loan purchasing the new goods. She promises to pay back the loan in time and thanks everyone for their support. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was a key post along the Silk Road and is where the rule of Alexander the Great ended. It is famous for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase her range of goods

loans.name: Ahmatillo

texts.en:
Since his youth, P. Ahmatillo has been in touch with the countryside. His family dedicated themselves to cultivating fruits and vegetables and he imagined he’d be in the business of selling produce. Fortunately, he has realized this dream. At the age of 22, he began to sell fruit and vegetables in small markets. Little by little, he saved money so he could set up his own shop. Thanks to his efforts and the love he has for this business, Ahmatillo’s enterprise has been growing gradually. Nevertheless, Ahmatillo believes it is time to inject more capital into the business so that he can buy at the wholesale level and obtain better prices. As a result, he is applying for a loan of 3500 Somoni, which he will repay in 9 months. With your help, Ahmatillo will be able to move his business forward and offer his wife and two children a better future. loans.use: Increase the range of vegetables for sale

loans.name: Alima

texts.en: Alima A. sells bags of rice and beans in Bodija market. This market is one of the largest markets in Ibadan, Nigeria. She sells her bags of beans and rice wholesale and retail to her customers. She needs the loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more bags of rice and beans to sell. She is 35 years old and married with 3 children. She says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of rice and beans to sell

loans.name: Mpakawero Lufuka- Hadija Nagita Group

texts.en:
Hadija N. (back; 3rd right) is 30 years old. She is married with 4 children who attend school. Hadija has 3 years of experience operating a restaurant and a retail shop. Her menu comprises of local dishes and snacks. On the other hand, her retail shop is also stocked with fast moving consumer goods.

Hadija needs a loan to boost both businesses by purchasing foodstuffs for the restaurant and some commodities for the retail shop. This hardworking lady hopes to run a wholesale shop in future. The income from the businesses enables her to support her husband in fending for the family.

This is a group loan, where each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs for the restaurant and some commodities for her retail shop.

loans.name: Boirjon

texts.en:
Boirjon is 38 years old and the father of two children. His wife is a housekeeper and she supports him in everything he does. He is a hard working person and has been providing taxi services for three years. The most important thing for him is that his children, in the future, enroll in school and finish University so that they will have better prospects as professionals. Boirjon wishes to keep his taxi business growing, and for this he needs to have his car in good working order. He needs to buy spare parts to repair it and is therefore requesting a loan. Thanks to his business, he has been able to stabilize his quality of life. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was a key post along the Silk Road and is where the rule of Alexander the Great ended. It is famous for it's great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others.
